ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A comprehensive introduction to computer engineering, how to use HDL languages, playing around with FPGAs, Booleans, etc
Learned about the basics of computer engineering from the circuits and logic level up to the hierarchical level.
I learned the background behind computers, logic gates and basic microarchitecture.

Introductory to intermediate knowledge of logic, digital circuit optimization, HDL (Verilog), assembly code, and other processor-related skills. Most broadly, you learn very well how to perform the abstraction necessary to think about more and more complex circuits--but first you've got to start at the ground level.
Learned how a computer worked from a low level

Hdl
Verilog
Computer engineering
Visualization, complex architecture
Programming and lab skills

I gained a deeper understanding of the layers of abstraction of modern computer architecture as well as how the low level components work. Further, I learned how to code in Verilog and work with FGA boards.
I learned various skills such as Boolean algebra, the inside of a computer, and some of the processors as well as how to program in Verilog, a hardware description language.
I learned the foundations of how digital circuits work with boolean algebra, learned how to code an Verilog HDL, and how the von Neumann computer model works.
Von neumann architecture, verilog, assembly and machine language, boolean algebra, logic design
I learned how to code, about computers, and how hardware interfaces with software in computer architecture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Only weakness is that the lecture notes are hard to understand/follow sometimes, but other than that:
great labs
cool content
jakub is a great professor, but he is always late for grading stuff, like it is past the credit/d/fail deadline rn and bro still hasnt graded our midterms, so i guess dont take this class if you think you might want to credit/d/fail it

I think the homework was a lot of busywork that didn't really test understanding. The courses greatest limitation is how quickly we move the a huge breadth of material, and I feel like a lot of the later and more complex topics didn't get enough time. Also, the grading was very slow, basically got 90% of out grades back during reading week which is not that helpful.

I believe I learn by practice quite a bit so the sporadic homework assignments did not feel spaced out well enough for me. However, the lectures were good. The labs helped with learning material but often were quite difficult in that I felt like some manuals did not lead you through the lab very well or it was hard to directly connect material back to lectures.
The course greatly simplifies very complicated topics, but I feel like we didn't learn much because of it.

I absolutely hate slides. To thrive, I need a very active learning environment with discussion, teamwork, and in-class practice problems that demonstrate the concepts we are learning in class. Unfortunately, that is not what this class is. After a while, I grew to hate going to class. All my other classes were so much more engaging and I was beginning to worry I had picked the wrong major (Electrical Engineering), but when I began studying (cramming, really) on my own for the final, I realized the content was really amazing. I didn't really feel that the class had any notable strengths, other than perhaps the kind grading system.
Learned a ton
The course is really well organized and provides a great introduction to boolean algebra and computer architecture.

Strengths:
- Good problems for practice
- Great support from the professor
- Great introduction to boolean algebra and all circuit related
- Great book resource
- Good pace

Weaknesses:
- Very very very late grading. The only thing they graded very very fast was the final.
- The p-sets (the first 3) are extremely extremely long. Could take up to 30 hours. This makes the course tedious and shows the professor is not very well at doing assignments.
- The exams were weird and we barely had time to finish. However, I must say, the curves were very very fair.
- Sometimes a bit disorganized in terms of p-set release... 
- The LABS. The only way to finish labs was either with Anthony or Kevin's help. HOWEVER, they were very long and almost had topics that we hadn't seen in class yet. 
- Overall, the time committed to this class was that of 3 courses.
Lab load is high and skills not taught in lecture
Lectures go very slowly at some points and then rush very confusing topics.
Split up verilog and digital systems, not enough of each on their own
The strengths of this course are that the labs provide such a good way for you to understand the concepts you come across in lecture

The course has a lab which isn't too bad, but the course content is a little independent from the lab. Which has good and bad aspects because you are learning more things in a hands on setting but also because you aren't exposed to things and can get stuck.
We went pretty in depth and the content was interesting, more direct practice.
Assignments and lab were very fun but grading was done so late that the feedback was unhelpful.

I liked the labs. The slides were thorough but slightly repetitive. That's not necessarily a bad thing. In my opinion, there weren't enough psets to really practice the material. I think there should have been a pset every week but that the psets should have been shorter.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: absolutely recommend it to any cs and engineering kid
It's required, labs are kinda cool.
It is required for the EE major. When making your schedule, don't stress out about this course. Yes, there is a lab but it does not take too much time, especially as there is no lab report.

A recommendation doesn't matter here. If it's required for your major, take it, and please try not to let it scare you away. The Electrical Engineering department at Yale is infamous for its less-than-ideal professors, but you will learn how to deal with it and grow in the process--and maybe you'll even learn to appreciate the good professors you're lucky enough to experience. If this class is not required for your major, I certainly wouldn't recommend taking it, unless you're considering Electrical Engineering.
Yes, taught very well, extremely interesting

Yes. The labs were very useful and fun to work on, and built on top of each other while also reinforcing the concepts taught in class. I also really enjoyed having a practical midterm that was manageable.
It is a major requirement
Yes
Yes, especially since it is an requirement for the EE major. However I would also encourage computer science students to take this course as well (goes well with CPSC 323)
I would if they are an engineering or cs major and it's required, otherwise I would not because of the lab is quite a time commitment
Yes, if interested in computer engineering and learning about the basics of how a computer works.
Yes. It was fun.
